Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Employment Skills to Enhance Diversity of the Geoscience Workforce During the National Association of Black Geoscientists Annual Conference
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide support to defray expenses of student participants attending the 35th Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG). The conference will take place in New Orleans on September 7-10, 2016. The primary goal of NABG is to mentor and advise students from under-represented backgrounds pursuing BS, MS, and PhD degrees in scientific, technical, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines, providing a competent and diverse workforce fulfilling critical national needs for the 21st Century. Professional members serve as role models to participating students, and engage in a number of mentoring activities including constructive criticism of student research projects, career counseling, guidance related to professional behavior and academic advising. A new component at the conference this year will be a pre-conference workshop where students will learn and practice non-technical skills. It is expected that providing this information prior to the conference will foster faster internalization of these newly acquired skills. The meeting serves as an opportunity for academic institutions, government agencies, and the energy/environmental industry to recruit students from underrepresented groups to STEM disciplines and employment in the national geosciences workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists engaged 41 students-of-color from 22 4-year colleges and univiersities across the United States. Representation included students from 15 majority institutions and 7 minority-serving institutions or historically black colleges.

All 41 student participants presented results of research in either oral or poster formats during the conference. Meeting breaks and organized poster sessions were opportunities for students to network with NABG professionals and for professionals to mentor students regarding academic skills and progress as well as career advice.

 The PI piloted a pre-meeting professional development workshop for student participants focused on networking and networking skills. All student participants were required to attend the workshop and it was well-received by students and observers from the NABG professional members who attended.

 Seasoned professional members of NABG presented a 1 hour panel discussion addressing the economic downturn in the global energy industry and shared their personal experiences weathering a similar downturn during the early 1980s. The panel members are distinguished professionals with combined experience in the energy industry exceeding 100 years. Their shared experiences reinforced the importance of networking for student participants and also emphasized the importance of persistence as a strategy for professional success as well as utlizing professional networks and accumulated social capital during episodes with difficult business climates.

 Meeting breaks permitted students to receive information from exhibitors representing geoscience-oriented professional societies, United States government agencies, national research laboratories, and academic institutions. Feedback from exhibitors regarding quality of student engagement and access to share information with students was uniformly positive.

 The conference closed with a 1/2-day field trip to the Lower 9th Ward, New Orleans - a location that was notably adversely impacted during Hurricane Katrina in 2005. The field trip group stopped to listen and learn about the crisis during and after Katrina from local activists. The field trip also toured rehabilitated neighborhoods in the Lower 9th Ward to learn about post-Katrina recovery and re-establishment of the community in this historically minority populace in New Orleans. 

 The specific objectives of this project were to introduce students-of-color to the National Association of Black Geoscientists. NABG is one of the oldest minority-serving professional geoscience organizations and the annual technical conference serves as an opportunity for professional members to engage, encourage, and enable upward-bound students toward professional employment in the national geosciences workforce. It is important for these students to meet and be mentored by geoscience professionals who share similar experiences educationally and socially.

 The conference also serves as a mechanism for students participants to engage in near-peer mentoring as undergraduates can meet and talk to graduate students (both MS and PHD level) and learn of their experiences in geosciences. Graduate students can meet and interact with recent graduates and newly-employed people like them. Many of these graduates and newly-employed members of the geosciences professions are alumni of prior participant support to NABG conferences.

 Continuity of contact with NABG through NSF support for student participants has proven to be an important mechanism to retain students-of-color in the pipeline leading to employment in the national geosciences workforce. To date, NSF sponsorship has enabled participation of over 300 students at the NABG annual conference. A number of these students have graduated with advanced geosciences degrees and joined the workforce. Two of the alumni are currently the annual conference chairs organizing the 2017 NABG annual conference in Atlanta (7-9 September 2017).

 NSF support for students at the NABG annual technical conference is responsible for a number of black students earning employment in the national geosciences workforce every year, and makes a contribution to broadening participation and increasing inclusion of African American and black people of other national origins in geosciences where their numbers remaing appallingly low (only 3.25% in 2016).
